b\. Rhizome and lower half of leafy stem.

c\. Rhizome and leafy stem, scape and detached sepal and flowers. Cultivated in a hothouse at Clapham Common from seeds received from the Botanic Gardens in Java; flowered 1 June, 1868; fruit apparently mature 15 Nov., 1868. Accompanying sheet e is a pencil drawing of the different organs of the flower and the following remarks: "A. Cardamomum, L.; 22 April, 1873. Staminodes 2, distinct. The stamen is prostrate on the labellum, not erect beneath the dorsal lobe of the outer perianth. There appears to be no horn-like process at the base of the labellum as in the African species. Ovary shaggy; the flat stigma is firmly lodged between the lobes of the anther, the style accommo- dating itself to the position by a convenient twist."
a\. Lower part of the stem with leaves and scape and detached seeds.
b\. Leaves. Cape Palmas, West Coast of Africa; Rev. A. Crummell; May, 1859. [Seeds small, angular, lea den grey, and glossy.]

species.speciesName: 530\. Anomum citratum, Pereira, (‘Pharm. Journ.,’ vol. ix., p. 313). (Mungulu of the Natives)

folders.description: a\. Leaf, detached fruit and seeds, and pencil drawing of inflorescence. River Gaboon, West Africa; No. 1052; G. Mann; 1861. "Grows 15 feet high."

b\. A second specimen of No. 1052. G. Mann; from the Royal Herbarium, Kew. An engraving of a village near the Gaboon river accom- panies this specimen. See 'Journ. Linn. Soc.,' vii., p. 110. c\. Root, stem, leaves, and detached fruits and seeds. No. 1051. Gaboon River, W. Africa; G. Mann; 1861.
a\. (1 and 2) Large leaf on two sheets. A drawing of inflorescence and flower accompanies this specimen.
b\. (1 and 2) Portion of stem, with large and small leaves on two sheets. This specimen shows the variation in the size of the leaf. See 'Journ. Linn. Soc.,' vii., p. 110.

species.speciesName: 532\. Amomum Granum-Paradisi\, L\., quoad Hook, f.

folders.description: a\. Rhizome\, with detached stem\, leaves\, and inflorescence\. Royal Botanic Gardens\, Trinidad\, ; grown from West African seeds sent by me\. The fruit has been sent in fluid\.—D\. H\. b\. Rhizome\, with stem\, detached leaves\, scape of fruit\, and detached seeds\. Sierra Leone\, ; Rev\. J\. Hall\, ; 1865\. Also flowers\, fruit and leaf in alcohol\. Plant\, 9 to 10 feet high\. The leaves were attached to the rhizome when received\. [The seeds taste like cajeput\.]

c\. Two leaves\, and tracing of scape and flower\. (1) Leaf of the plant figured in Bot\. Mag\.\. p\. 4603\. (2) Bot\. Gardens\, Trinidad\, W\. Indies\, ; from a plant raised from seeds which I sent\.—D\. H\. Attached to this specimen is a letter from Sir W\. J\. Hooker\, stating that specimens (corresponding with those from which the plant figured in Bot\. Mag\. were mised) are preserved in the Kew Herbarium\.

a\. Lower half of leafy stem leaves\. b\. Upper half of leafy stem\. Raised from seeds\, Clapham Common\; 27 Aug\.\, 1874\; D\. H\. c\. Rhizome\, stem\, and leaf\. Sierra Leone\; Dr\. W\. F\. Daniell\; Ex Herb\. Kew\. d\. Leaves\, and drawing of the fruits\. Specimens from Sierra Leone\; Rev\. J\. Hall\; 1865\. The leaves were sent dried\, the fruits in alcohol\. e\. Leaves\, fruit and seeds\. Prince's Island\; G\. Mann\; received Dec\.\, 1861\; no number\; adopted number\, 10548\. f\. Leaves\. Ex Herb\. Royal Garden\, Kew\; No\. 10548\; Island of St\. Thomas\, W\. Africa\; lat\. 6 o\; collected by G\. Mann\; received Nov\.\, 1861\. Drawing of flower\, 18 Jan\.\, 1862\. - D\. H\. Also coloured one of fruit received in fresh state from S\. A\. Benson\, 22 April\, 1853\. Grand Bassa\, with section of fresh fruit\, some seeds of which were sent to Rollison of Tooting\.

a\. Leaves and detached leaves\. Fernando Po\; “all through the forest\;” G\. Mann\; No\. 1171\. Flower light purple\. Plant 12ft\. high\. Received Jan\.\, 1862\, with the flowers and fruit in spirit\. [A drawing of the scape and flowers and fruit is also attached\.] [The seeds hardly differ in size\, colour\, shape\, or taste from those of A\. augutifolium\, but the shape of the flower and the smooth fruit a\.- represented in the drawing are unlike those of that species\.] For a description of this species\, see 'Jour\. Linn\. Soc\.,\' vol\. vii\.,\, p\. 110\.
b\. Ditto\. c\. Stem and leaves from plant in hothouse\; 10 Oct\.\, 1873\. Leaves spotted with red on the under side\.

species.speciesName: 535\. Amomum longiscapum\, Hook\.\, f\. (“Amomum sp\. X\.Y\.Z\.”)

folders.description: a\. Stem\, leaves\, and detached scape\. The scape from Dr\. Daniell\, Sierra Leone\, 1854\. The foliage gathered on 27 Aug\.\, 1874\. from a plant I raised at Clapham Common from seeds collected on Sugar Loaf Mountain\, Sierra Leone\, and given me by Mr\. Bockstall\, missionary\, 6 July\, 1871\.
b\. Ditto\. c\. Stem and leaves from plant in hothouse\; 10 Oct\.\, 1873\. Leaves spotted with red on the under side\.

a\. Leaves and drawing of inflorescence\. No\. 1902\. Gustav Mann\. Corisco Bay\, Oct\.\, 1862\. Plant four to five feet high\. The flowers are preserved in spirit at Kew\. See 'Jour\. Linn\. Soc\.,\' vol\. viii\.,\, page 110\.

a\. Rhizome\, stem leaves\, scapes of fruit and detached seeds\. Hangooas\, Java\; S\. Binnendyik\. Some seeds were sent to Kew\, 30 June\, 1871\. and others sowed at Clapham Common\, 22 June\, 1871\. [Seeds small elliptical\, dull brown\, taste unpleasant\, scarcely aromatic\.]

Small variety\. Rhizome and leaves\, and young fruit\. Sierra Leone\; Rev\. W\. Young\; 1854\. This is the small variety producing the small Grains of Paradise\. Dr\. Daniell gave me a fruit of this variety\, under the name of "Tokolo M'pomah"\. Vile Hooker in 'Journ\. Bot\.', vol\. vi\., p\. 293\.
Stem\, leaves\, and flower\. Cultivated in hothouse\, Clapham Common\; May\, 1873\.
Leaves only\. Ex Kew Herbarium\; Island of St\. Thomas\, West Africa\; G\. Mann\; No\. 1054A\; received Nov\., 1861\.

Detached leaves and scape and seeds\. Prince's Island\; Gustav Mann\; (no number\, adopted number 1054b)\; received Dec\., 1861\. A pencil drawing of 1054n\, by D\. H\., accompanies sheet\, and a coloured drawing of a fruit with a pencil sketch of a transverse section of a fruit\, received in the fresh state from S\. A\. Benson\, Grand Bassa\, Liberia\; 22 April\, 1853\.

Stem\, leaves\, and fruit\. Anamallies\, in dense\, moist forests\, 2\,000 to 3\,000 feet elevation\. Flowers in July\; from Capt\. Beddome\; 1861\. A drawing by Fitch of the dissected flower and fruit\, and a sketch of the structure of the stigma by D\. H\. accompanies this specimen\.

b\. Stem, leaf, and detached dissected flower\. Both these specimens are marked in pencil, but not in D. H.'s writing\. Probably A\. hypoleucum\, Thw\. 540\. Amomum pilosum\, O\. and H\. a\. Stem and leaves and detached seeds\. No\. 1415\; G\. Mann\; Fernando Po\; 1862\; 6-8 feet high\; corolla yellow\. Drawings of flower and fruit accompany this specimen\. [Seeds very small with large double arillus]\. See 'Journ\. Linn\. Soc\.,' vol\. vii\.\. p\. 110\. 541\. Amomum rostratum\, O\. and H\. (non A\. ceruum\, Hook\.\. f\.)\. Hook\. 'Journ\. Bot\.,' vol\. vi\. (1854)\; p\. 296\. a\. Stem, leaves, and detached fruit and seeds\. Cape Palmas\, West Coast of Africa\; Rev\. A\. Crummell\; received May\., 1859\. [Seeds leaden grey, angular, polished, slightly aromatic\.] b\. Upper half of leafy stem\. c\. Ditto\. 542\. Amomum sceptrum\, O\. and H\. ('Journ\. Linn\. Soc\.,' vii\.\. p\. 109\.)\. a\. Leaves and detached fruit and seeds\. River Gaboon\; July\., 1861\. very common at Ambas Bay, where it borders the shore\; grows 6 feet high\; G\. Mann\; No\. 1034\. Flowers in spirit at Kew\. A drawing of the flowers and sketch of the fruit, which is "attached to a scape about 8 inches long" accom- panies this specimen\. [Seeds brown, angular, glossy, faintly aromatic\.] b\. Leaves and detached seed\. Old Calabar\; W\. G\. Milne\; received Oct\., 1863\. One of the leaves is from jar No\. 5, containing the fruit from which the seeds were taken\. The remainder of the leaves are from a bundle K, sent at the same time, but of which the label could not be found\. With flowers and fruit in spirit\. [The seeds are larger and more tapering below than those of specimen a\.] c\. Leaves and scape, with fruit and detached seeds\.  From bottle ; W\. G\. Milne ; No\. 17\. d\. Leaves and scape with fruit\. Akassa, River Nun ; March—April, 1865 ; No\. 3; E\. J\. L\. Simmonds\. With specimens in alcohol; no flowers\. A sketch of fruit is attached to this sheet\. c\. Leaf and detached fruits and seeds\. Akassa, River Nun ; No\. 1; E\. J\. L\. Simmonds; March—April, 1865\. With specimens in alcohol\. A drawing of the flower is also attached to this specimen\. more\.: E\. J\. L\. S\.’s letters; 9 Mar\., 5 April, 1865\. f\. Stem and leaves\. From a seedling plant, cultivated at Clapham ; 1867\. g\. Rhizome, with lower half of leafy stem\. Hothouse at Clapham ; 24 Sept\., 1872\. h\. Upper half of leafy stem of specimen g\.

speciesName: 543\. Anomum subsericeum\, O\. and H\. 'Journ\. Linn\. Soc\.,' vol\. vii\.\. p\. 100 (Yange) folders: [{'description': 'a\\. Leaf and seeds\\. No\\. 1 ; R\\. Walker, Gaboon ; five to six feet high\\. Fruit and leaves in acetic acid\\. (Seeds of the same size and shape as b\\.)'}]

b\. Leaves and detached fruit and seeds\. No\. 1\; 904\, G\. Mann\, Gaboon River and Corisco Bay\; Oct\.\, 1862\; the plant grows from 10 to 12 feet high\. The underside of the leaf covered with fine short tomentum\. Flowers and fruit in spirit sent to Kew\. A drawing of rhizome\, scape\, and flower\, is attached to this sheet\. (The seeds of this specimen are of a greenish brown colour\, and are very like those of A\. angustifolium\.)
c\. Leaves\. Old Calabar\; Rev\. W\. G\. Milne\; received Oct\.\, 1863\.
a\, b\. Leaves and detached fruit\. From Col\. Richard C\. Lawrence\, Resident\, Nepal\; received 23 Jan\.\, 1872\; per Dr\. Clegghorn\. "Dry Cardamoms\; crop of 1870\."

c\. Leaves\. From C\. H\. Wood\, Runghbee\, Darjeeling\; received 24 Oct\.\, 1874\. Flowers of Nepal cardamoms\, preserved in spirit\; dried leaves wrapped around the bottle\. (See 'Journ\. Linn\. Soc\.,' vol\. xvii\.,\, p\. 5\.)
a\. Rhizomes\, and scales of fruits\. From the Hon\. J\. T\. Gibson\, Cape Palmas\; 1873\.
b\. Leaves and pencil sketch of ligule\. This specimen is marked : "Amomum\, remarkable for its long acute ligule\." From the Hon\. J\. T\. Gibson\, Cape Palmas\; March\, 1873\.
c\. Leaves\. Cape Palmas\; Rev\. J\. T\. Gibson\; March\, 1873\.
a\. Leaves\. Cape Palmas\; Rev\. C\. C\. Hoffmann\; 1865\; with flowers and fruits in alcohol\. This species has a ribbed fruit\.

b\. Seedling plant attached to seed\. Sent by N\. Wilson in 1867 as A\. Melangela\, Roxb\. but it is not that species\. [The seeds resemble in appearance those of A\. sylvicre\. See Bencinainia sylvicre (No\. 557\.)]

a\. Rhizome\, scape\, stem\, leaves\, and detached fruits\. From R\. Hunter\, Bangkok\, Siam\; 1857\; grows 10 feet high\. A detached scape of mature fruit from the Rev\. C\. Parish is fastened on the same sheet\.
b\. Ditto\. From R\. Hunter\, Bangkok\; 1857\.
a\. Scape of flowers and fruit\. Ceylon\; March\, 1836\; from Dr\. Wright\; Feb\.\, 1863\. "Has a very large leaf\; the fruit comes very near that of A\. xanthioides\, Wall\."
a\. Stem and leaves\. No\. 77\, Mann\; of the garden list\, Kew\.

a\. Leaves\. Grand Bassa\, Liberia\; 10 Feb\., 1853\; S\. A\. Benson\; No\. 17\. "The pulp of the fruit\, which has an agreeable acid taste\, is eaten\, and its juice used medicinally\. Fruits and leafy stems attached to rhizome sent in acetic acid".

a\. Rhizome\, leaves and flowering scape\. Ayamalay Forests\; Capt\. Beddome\. b\. Ditto\. With specimens of flowers and fruit in alcohol\. Amomum muricatum\, Beddome\, MS8\. A drawing of the dissected flowers labelled\, Elettaria cannaecarpa\, Wight\, is attached to this sheet\. c\. Ditto\. Ayamalay Forests\; Capt\. Beddome\.
a\. Rhizome and base of stem\. Cultivated under the name of E\. Cardamomum\, Maton\, but has never flowered\. Oct\.\, 1865\; D\. H\.
b\. Upper part of leafy stem\. Var\. # major\. a\. Leaf a flowering scape\. Ant\. Prov\. Ceylon ; March\, 1866\; G\. W\. H\. Thwaites\.
b\. Leafy stem\, with flower scape\. Ayamalay\, near Paulaghant ; Sept\.\, 1850\; Ex Herb\. Wight\; 22 June\, 1859\.

species.speciesName: 553\. Elettaria speciosa\, Bl\. : var\. fructibus purpureis\.

folders.description: a\. Leaves\. Tepoes Bener\, Java ; S\. Binnendyky ; received 1865\. [Seeds small\, elliptical\, angular\, greyish black\, nearly tasteless\.]
a\. Flowering branch\. Siam ; T\. Christy\, Jr\. ; 1867\.

a\. Inflorescence and dissected flower\. Cultivated specimen\; 1861\; grown in England\. b\. Leaves and detached seed\. Seed large\, greyish\, almost plano-convex\, with a brownish branched arillus\. Flavour strongly aromatic\, resembling a mixture of cummin and turpentine\. At the back of sheet b the following memorandum occurs :
a\. Slender rhizome and leaves\. The plant is said to afford the rhizome sold as "Kapur Kachri" ; from near Swatow\, China\; 1872\. [The taste of the rhizome is very similar to that of the drug\.]

a\. Stem and scape\, and detached leaves\, fruit\, and seed\. Jamaica\; Mr\. Wilson\; 1861\. [Seeds angular\, brown\, glossy\, having a bitter taste\, and a flavour intermediate between that of lemon and opium\.] [Seeds angular brown\, glossy\, having a bitter taste and a flavour intermediate between lemon and opium\.]
a\. Stem\, leaves\, and flower\. Hothouse\, Clapham Common\; 1873\.

species.speciesName: 559\. [Thunnttococcus Danielli\, Bth\. & Hook\.] Monostiche Danielli\, Horan\.

folders.description: a\. Stem\, leaf\, and fruit\. Ambas Bay\, W\. Trop\. Africa\; 1859-1863\. Collected by G\. Mann\. Ex\. Herb\., Kew\.
a\. Plant in flower\, with rhizome\. Cultivated in the garden at Clapham Common\; 11 Oct\., 1866\.
a\. Entire plant in flower\. Garden\, Clapham Common\; 11 Oct\., 1868\.
a\. Flower and dissections of flower\. Clapham Common\, cultivated\; Oct\., 1855\.
a\. Plant in flower\. Col de Lautaret\, Dauphiné\; June\, 1857\.
b\. Entire plant and dissected flowers\. March\, 1866\. (No locality)
a\. Flowering stem\, with male flowers\. Near Lindfield\, Sussex\; 21 July\, 1855\. b\. With fruit\. Hertford Heath\; 16 Sept\.\, 1854

a\. Leafy stem\. b\. Leafy stem\. c\. Ditto in fruit\. Toulon\; May\, 1854\. [In a the leaves have the cordate base turned outwards\, giving a hastate aspect to the leaves\. Those of b are turned inwards\, so that the leaves appear more truly cordate or nearly reniform\. In the fruiting twig c the leaves are smaller and cordate-lanceolate\.]

d\. Two flowering stems and fruiting twig\. Between Safed and Mijdel Keram\; climbing the trees\; very fine\. Common about Beyrout\, Syria\; Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker and D\. Hanbury\; Sept\. and Oct\., 1860\. [The three twigs on sheet d all show a wide divergence in the form of the bracts\, being cordate-triangular in one\, elongate-hastate in the second\, and broadly cordate-ovate in the third\.]
a\. Flowering twig\. Hort\. Bot\. ; Grenoble ; 19 June, 1857 ; M\. Verlot\. ("Smilax Mauritanica" of the Bot\. Gardens\.)

species.speciesName: 570\. [Smilax ornata\, Hook\. f\.] Smilax officinalis\, H\. B\. K\.

folders.description: a\. Leaves\. b\. Leaves\. c\. Leaf and stem\. d\. Leaf and roots\. a\. Royal gardens\, Kew ; 15 Sept\., 1873\. b\. Ditto ; 21 March, 1871\. These specimens have quadrangular stems with compressed prickles at the angles\, and a few prickles on the midrib of the leaves\, and the roots have the orange tint of the Jamaica root\. a\. Leaves and quadrangular prickly stem and detached roots\. Government Botanical gardens\, Castleton\, Jamaica ; received from J\. H\. Kemble\, Kingston\, Jamaica ; 2 Dec\., 1871\. [The stems are quadrangular\, with compressed prickles at the angles\, and the leaves are oblong lanceolate\, not cordate as in the Kew plant\; the roots correspond in appearance with the orange-coloured Jamaic sarasaparilla of commerce\.] c\. Leaves only\. d\. Flowering twig and detached flower\. Sarasaparilla from Patis\, New Granada ; R\. B\. White ; 1869\. In an extract from a letter by Mr\. White to Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\, Mr\. White says : "My Patis Smilax has a quadrangular stem with thorns on the angles\, and all the common sorts have round stems\." e\. Flowering twig and detached flower\. Aspinwall ; along the sea beach\, climbing over bushes ; 15 Sept\., 1862 ; No\. 638 ; S\. Hayes\. [Leaves small\, lanceolate\, coriaceous ; stem round\, not prickly\.] f\. Leafy twig\, with fruit\. River Sogamozo\, New Granada ; Jno\. Weir ; 1864\. To this specimen is attached an extract from the "Proc\. Roy\. Hort\. Soc\.", May\, 1864\, relating to this plant\. g\. Seedling plants (two specimens\. (1) Grown from seeds brought from the river Sogamozo\, New Granada\, by J\. Weir\, 1864\. (2) Seedling plant found in commercial Sarasaparilla\; E\. A\. Webb\; 1871\. h\. Flowering twig with detached section of stem\. River Sogamozo\, New Granada\; J\. Weir\; 1864\. Received with flowers and fruit in alcohol and dried root and stem\. [The stem is rounded with horizontal woody prickles\.] With these specimens are tracings of "3789\, Caudex tennis teres\, flores pellide virides Fl\. Negro ad fluv\. Xiberi otho\, Dec\., 1854\,: nd "160\,

a\. Leafy stem with detached fruits\. Common about Panama\; June\., 1862\; Sutton Hayes\; No\. 630\. b\. Leafy stem of female plant with flowers and detached flowers\. Common in the woods about Panama\; 25 Sept\.\, 1862\; S\. Hayes\. [Stem round\, furrowed with horizontal laterally compressed prickles\, and a few prickles on lower side of midrib\.]
a\. Flowering twig\. Viti or Fiji Islands\. Collected by Dr\. B\. Seemann\. 1860\. [See Seemann Fl\. Vit\., p\. 310\.]
a\. Flowering branch\. [India 1 No locality given\.]

a\. Entire plant in flower with the rhizome attached\. Tanhay\, near Tournier\, 28 April\, 1866\. b\. Flowering stem and detached flower (two specimens\. (1) Bois de Boulogne\, Paris\, 23 April\, 1854\. (2) Vienn (Isère)\, 27 April\, 1854\.
a\. Stem with flowers and fruit (two specimens)\. (1) Gerardmer\, Vosges\; 12 Aug\.\, 1855\. (2) Grande Chartreuse\; 15 June\, 1857\. b\. Stem with flowers\. Grande Chartreuse\; 12 Aug\.\, 1857\.
a\. Flowering and fruiting spikes\. Beyrout\, Syria\; Sept\.-Oct\., 1860\; Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker and D\. Hanbury\. “Extremely common throughout the country\. ”-D\. H\.
a\. Flowering plant with corm (two specimens)\. (1) Near Clermont Ferrand\, Auvergne\; Sept\.\, 1858\. (2) Hallstadt (Austria)\; Sept\.\, 1862\.
a\. Leaf\, inflorescence\, and detached flowers\. St\. Maurice\, Vosges\, 16 Aug\.\, 1855\.

a\. Leaf and spadix (without flowers\. Lake of Tiberias\; 30 Oct\., 1860\; Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker and D\. H\. Stunted plants forming tufts 6-8 ft\. high\, growing near the shore of the Lake of Tiberias at Mejidal and Tell Hûm\. Fruit stalk seen on one plant only\. D\. H\.
a\. Plant in flower\, with detached spadix\. Hitchin\, Herefordshire\; May\, 1856\.
a\. Entire plant in flower\, with corn attached and detached spadix\. From a root received from Prof\.\, W\.\, Proctor\, Jr\.\, of Philadelphia\, ; 1867\.
a\. Leaf and spadix\. Angers\, France\, 10 June\, 1862\, ; T\. W\. Beddome\.
a\. Entire plant in flower\, with rhizome attached\. Near Petit Bo Bay\, Guernsey\, ; 3 Sept\.\, 1859\, ; H\. Groves\.
a\. Plant in flower\, without rhizome\. Smyrna\; 20 Sept\.\, 1860\; Dr\. J\. H\. Hooker and D\. H\.
a\. Colm\. E\. C\. Hulah\, 'Plants of Southern Syria'\; R\. T\. Lowne\; 1863-4\.

species.speciesName: 586\. Andropogon citratus\, D\.\. C\.\. (A\.\. Schoenanthus\, Wall\.\., non L\.\; A\.\. Schoenanthus\, Roxb\.\., non L\.\.)

folders.description: a\. Leafy stem\. Kew Gardens\; 17 Aug\., 1858\.

b\. Leafy stem\. Received from Major Heber Drury\, Travancore\; 10 Feb\., 1860\. "From this species\, and this only\, Lemon Grass oil is distilled in Travancore\."—Major Drury's letter\; 19 Aug\., 1859\."

c\. Leafy stem\. Bandong\, Java\, Dr\. J\. E\. de Vrij\; 27 June\, 1860\. "Called Sreeh in Java\, where it does not grow wild\, but is frequently cultivated and'seems not to bear flowers\.' The essential oil obtained by Dr\. de Vrij from this plant was found by him to be inactive to the polarized ray\."

d\. Leafy stem\. "Cultivated\, as well as the Citronelle grass\, by J\. A\. Hume\, at Watwalla\, about four miles from Galle\, Ceylon\, at which place\, however\, according to Mr\. Hume\, it never produces its flowers\. It is the plant from which'Lemon grass oil'is distilled\."—D\. H\. Collected by Theo\. Hanbury\; Nov\., 1858\.
c\. Leaves and inflorescence\. "The plant which yields the Lemon grass of Travancore\. Abundant on the plains\; it is not cultivated\. From E\. J\. Waring\, Travancore\, 1863\."
f\. Leafy stem\. Raised from seed obtained from pressed specimens of the grass given me by E\. J\. Waring\, 1863\.—D\. H\.
a\. Inflorescence\. Nepal\; Dr\. Wallich\, from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\.\, 1859\. [It has a Lemon grass flavour\.]

a\. Plant in flower\. Nunklow\, Khasaya\, 3\,000 to 5\,000 feet\; 10 July\, 1850\. Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\., 1859 (No\. 1594\, Herb\. Hooker\. [Taste bitter and camphorescent\, aromatic\, not like either citronelle\, verbena\, or ginger grass\.] b\. Ditto\. A diseased specimen\. Khasaya\; Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\., 1859\.

a\. Tufts of root leaves\, and portions of detached inflorescence (two specimens)\. On this sheet are specimens marked : (1) Bought at Milan\, with a pencil sketch of the original bundle purchased there\. (2) Found in an old collection of Materia Medica\, formerly belonging to Sir J\. E\. Smith\, 1863 ; "Juncus coloratus\, Ficaria Verna\, Schenanthus vel Spinauthus officinalis\, Elytris Dioscoridis et Galeni ; Adther Arabum\." Detached flowers\, received from Professor Guibourt\, are attached to this sheet\.
b\. Leafy stems\. Bought in a drug shop in bazaar at Damascus\; Oct\. 1860\.

c\. Plant in flower (two specimens)\. (1) Metlili\, (Mzab) Algeria\; E\. Cosson\, 12 May\, 1858\; received 16 Nov\. 1860\. (2) E\. Bourgau\, Plantes d'Algérie\, 1856\, No\. 56\. Colours of arts près de Cyant umbrosus of the province d'Oran\. Coll\. Kralik\, 9 Mai\.

d\. Plant in flower\. Lieux 'rocallieux à Metlili (Mzab)\; E\. Cosson\; 12 May\, 1858\. A description of the plant\, from "Exploration Sciratique de l'Algérie\, Botanique\, Phanerogamique" by Messrs\. M\. Cosson and Durieu de Maissoneuve\, tom\. 17\. p\. 48\, is attached to this sheet\.
e\. Ditto\. From the same locality and collectors\; received 16 Nov\.

species.speciesName: 1866. Andropogon laniger, var. longe-ristata (fide Munro). (A. circinatus, Hochst).

folders.description: a\. Plant in flower (two specimens). Seinde; Dr. J. E. Stocks, from J. D. Hooker; 18 Jan., 1859. "Aromatic, like A. laniger, Desf."—D. H. Andropogon laniger, var. punilus (fide Munro). a\. Plant in flower. Lahore, Aug., 1846; Dr. J. D. Hooker; 18 Jan., 1857. b\. Plant in flower. North-west India; Dr. Royle, from Dr. J. D. Hooker; 18 Jan., 1859. c\. Plant in flower (two specimens). (1) Iskardo, 8,000 feet, Western Thibet; Dr. Thomson; (2) Ludale, 11,000 feet, Western Thibet; Dr. Thomson; from Dr. J. D. Hooker; 18 Jan., 1859. d\. Plant in flower (three specimens). (1) North-west India (A. punilus, Roxb.); fide Royle). (2) Havallagh, Kumaon, June, 1845; Dr. T. Thomson. (3) Paoree, Gurwhal June, 1845; from Dr. J. D. Hooker; 18 June, 1859. c\. Plant in flower. Lahore, Aug., 1846; from Dr. J. D. Hooker; 18 Jan., 1859. f\. Plant in flower. Punjab, Dr. Thomson; from Dr. J. D. Hooker, 18 Jan, 1859.

a\. Plant in flower, and detached flowers\. A\. Iwarancusa, Blane in Herb. Roxb., fide Wallich, Catal, No. 8793; Dr. Wallich\. (“Very aromatic.”—D\. Hanbury\.). From Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker; 18 Jan\., 1859\. “Col\. Munro admits this to be the true A\. Iwarancusa of Roxburgh, but adds that it is the A\. Schonanthus of Nees von Esenbeck, Blane and of Sir J\. E\. Smith; 30 Nov\., 1860\.”—D\. H\. b\. Leaves and detached spikelet\. “Andropogon,” Called Khaviika-tel\. Ludiana; T\. W\. H\. Tolbort; 1869\. [It has a rose-geranium flavour\.].
a\. Inflorescence\. Cultivated; Campinas, Prov\. Sao Paulo, Brazil; J\. Correa de Mello.

a\. Detached leaves and flowers\. Received from G\. H\. K\. Thwaites\, 21 Oct\., 1859\. Who sent it under the name of A\. Schonanthus\, stating it be the source of citronelle oil\. (In a letter\, dated Ceylon\, 23 Dec\., 1853\.)\. Very abundant in Ceylon up to an elevation of 3,000 feet\. A\. Nardus (fide Munro)\. [The leaves have a citronelle flavour\.]\.

b\. c\. d\. Three portions of one plant\. Pangiri-maana grass\. (Andropogon Schonanthus\, var\. fide Thwaites\.)\. Ceylon\; from G\. H\. K\. Thwaites\, May\, 1859\. Length to summit of flower spike nearly seven feet\. c\. Plant in flower\. Watwalla\, about four miles from Galle\, Ceylon\. Cultivated by Mr\. J\. A\. Hume and gathered by Thomas Hanbury\; Nov\., 1858\. The oil of citronelle is distilled by Mr\. Hume from this grass\. [Specimen c has a rose- geranium\, not a citronelle flavour\.]\.

f\. g\. h\. Plants in flower\. (A\. Nardus\, L\.!) Cultivated in the Island of Mauritius\; received from L\. Bouton\, Mauritius\; 30 May\, 1859\. No essential oil distilled from it there\. This grass is of Wright's Catalogue and Herbarium\, No\. 1692\, Andropogon (Anatherum) Bouchaghi\, N\. E\. ; Andropogon (Anatherum) Schenauthus\, Roxb\. ; now L\. nee Wall\. Pl\. As\. rar\., vol\. 3\, t\. 280\. It is also No\. 303\, Mergui\, Griffith\, in Herb\. Wight's\; D\. H\. ; 24 June\, 1859\. [The taste of the Mauritius plant is fainter than the citronelle grass\, and between it and ginger grass\.]\.

i\. Leaves\. “Lemon grass\. ” Bath\, Jamaica\; N\. Wilson\; April\, 1860\. j\. Leaves and flowers\. Bath\, Jamaica\; Nov\., 1859\. The culm measured 10 feet\, and from 9 to 12 inches between the nodes\. Colonel Munro marked this A\. Nardus\, L\.!\.

k\. Flowering stem\. l\. Plant\, with flowers and root\. Courtaulm\, Madras\; G\. Thomson\, from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\., 1859\. A\. Martha\, Roxb\. (fide Munro)\, but after further examination referred by him to A\. Nardus\, L\. “This grass appears to be the1700 c\. Andropogon (Cinch\. ) orin\, N\. E\. ; y\. clatior\, culino coccio frons of Dr\. Wight's Catalogue\, and of his own herbarium\; ” D\. H\. ; 24 June\, 1859\. [It does not taste of citronelle\, but has an aromatic taste recalling that of patchouli\.]\.

Andropogon Nardus\, var\. Sexnosus\, Nees (fide Munro)\; (A\. confertiflorus\, Stend\. ; A\. nardooides\, f\. major\, Hochst\. ) a\. Plant in flower\. Madras\, Presidency\; G\. Thomson\, from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\., 1859\. Munro first referred it to A\. Schenauthus\, L\. [This grass has a bitter cam- phoraceous taste like that of A\. Khasinns\, but not at all resembling citronelle\.]\.

b\. Plant in flower\. (A\. Sexnosus\, var\. muticus\, fide Munro\.)\. Received from G\. H\. K\. Thwaites under the name of Andropogon Schenauthus\; 30 May\, 1859\. c\. Flowering top\. (A\. flexuosus\, var\. muticus\, fide Munro\.)\. “Maana” grass\. Said to afford but little oil\, and not of good quality\. Ceylon\; G\. H\. K\. Thwaites\; 30 May\, 1859\. Munro says it is only a variety of A\. Nerdus\, L\. [The taste of b and c differ from that of A\. Nerdus\, var\. flexuosus\, being slightly pungent with hardly any flavour\.]\.

a\. Leafy stems\. Ceylon\; May\, 1859\. "Saira grass\. Andropogon Nerdus\.: Lemon grass oil is extracted from this by ordinary distillation\."- G\. H\. K\. Thwaites\. [This is certainly a ginger grass\, and has the rose flavour of that oil and not of verbena\.]"

b\. Flowering stem\. (A\. pachnodes\, Trin\. ; A\. nardoides\, Nees\.)
Nepal\; Dr\. Wallich\, from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\., 1859\. [This has a mixed flavour of rose and caraway\.]
c\. Ditto\. Srinuggur\, Gurwhal\; June\, 1845\; T\. Thomson\; from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\, 18 Jan\., 1859\.

d\. Plant in flower\. Ex Herb\. Wight\; 22 June\, 1859\. In Wight's catalogue thus: "1702\, Andropogon (Cymb\.)\, Martius\, Roxb\. ; A\. nardoides\, N\. E\. Mast\. ; A\. pachnodes\, Trin\." [This specimen has the same taste as lemon grass\, i\.e\.\. like verbena\.]
r\. Stem and inflorescence\. Ex Herb\. H\. Deane\; 1859 (5 feet 9 inches high).

f\, g\, h\. Plants in flower\. Ex Herb\. H\. Deane\; 28 Jan\., 1830\. [These specimens have densely tufted\, short\, and narrow leaves\, a bitterish taste\, and a caraway flavour\, quite unlike a\, c\, and h\, which have the characteristic taste of ginger grass oil\.]

i\. Stem and inflorescence\. Raised in Brazil\, at Campinas\, Prov\. Sao Paulo\, Brazil\, by J\. Correa de Mello\, from seeds sent to me from India by D\. S\. Kemp\, of Bombay\. - D\. H\. j\. Flowering stem\. Raised in hothouse from seeds received from Mr\. Kemp\, "Bombay\; as seeds of grass yielding Indian grass oil\, from Indore\; and sowed 13 May\, 1867\. Some sent to Correa de Mello\, 7 Nov\, 1868\; and some to Thwaites\, 1 Oct\, 1868\." k\. Flowering stem\. Coromandel f G\. Thomson\. From Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\, 1859\. [This specimen has a ginger grass flavour\.] l\. Flowering top\. Dr\. Royle\. From Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\, 1859\. e\, f\, g\, h and l have a caraway almost turpentine flavour\. m\. Leafy stem and inflorescence (1 and 2)\. (1) Nunklow\, Khasya\; Dr\. Hooker\; 10 July\, 1850\, at 3\,000 ft\. to 4\,000 ft\. ; No\. 1\,594 Herb\. Hooker\; from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 15 Jan\, 1859\. "Compared with Linnæus's specimens of A\. Schenanthus by Dr\. Hooker and myself\, 20 Jan\, 1859\." A label\, appa- rently in Munro's writing\, states: "I am sorry I cannot coincide with this identification\. No\. I is not A\. Schenanthus\, L\. it is A\. citriodorus\, D\. C\. ; A\. Schenanthus\, Wall\. non Linn\." No\. 2 is Andropogon Khasianus\, Munro\; distinguished by the numerous nerves to the lower glumes\. [The taste of No\. 2 certainly more nearly resembles that of Khasianus than of that of the ginger grass oil plant\.] n\. Leafy stem and flowers (two specimens)\. (1) Deyra Dhoon\, Kunnan ; T\. Thomson\. (2) Sikkin ; from Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\, 1859\. Col\. Munro's label on this sheet states that No\. 1 is Andropogon Nardus\, var\. Silicetorum\, Munro\; and that No\. 2 is Andropogon citriodorus\, D\. C\. ; A\. Schenanthus\, Wall\. non Lin\. [No\. 2 tastes like coriander\.] o\. Stem\, leaves\, and flowers (two specimens)\. On summits of arid mountains in Mauritius\; L\. Bouton ; 30 May\, 1859\. Andropogon pachnodas\, Trin\. - D\. H\. Col\. Munro's label states: "A Schonanthus\, L\. var\. pratinae Nees\; also foliatus\, Steud\. It is not Cymbopogon elegans\, Sprengel\, which is a very different plant\." Another label\, in a different\, probably that of L\. Bonton's handwriting\, states: "Cymbopogon elegans\, Sprengel\; Andropogon cymbalaria\, L\. Pulgo "Citronelle Sauvage\." [This has the peculiar rose geranium flavour of true ginger grass oil\.] p\. Plant in flower\. A\. Schonanthus L\. (fide Munro after second examination\.) At first named by him A\. Martini\, Roxb\. From Dr\. Wight\, 22 June\, 1859\, who considers it to be the A\. Schonanthus of Wildenow\. Marked in Wight's Catalogue thus: "1806\, Andropogon (Cymbo- pogon) Schonanthus\, Linn\.; A\. Javanensis Roxb\."; and in Dr\. Wight's Herbarium his specimen is marked in Dr\. Rotter's handwriting thus: "Andropogon Schonanthus\, Manda p\. pillow T\." [This specimen has a caraway and turpentine flavour\.]

q\. Stem, leaves and flowers\. Sydapot\, Madras\; G\. Thomson\, No\. 298\; April\., 1845\. From D\. J\. Hooker\; 18 Jan\.\, 1859\. A\. Schonanthus\, L\. (fide Munro)\; A\. Martini\, Roxb\. (fide Munro)\; A\. census\, Nees\. G\. Thomson\. r\. Plant\, with leaves\, inflorescence and root\. From the same locality\. [The flavour resembles that of a mixture of rose and caraway\.]
a\. Flowering stem\. Sutlej\, Rampur\; Dr\. J\. D\. Hooker and D\. Hanbury 18 Jan\.\, 1859\. [This grass has a pungent taste\, with a slight flavour of peppermint\.]
a\. Leaves and flowering top\. Tarascon\; 17 Oct\., 1859\.
a\. Plant in fruit\. Addiscombe\, near Croydon\; 1873\.
a\. Plant in fruit\, with root attached\. Reggio\, Calabria\; 15 May\, 1872\.
a\. Plant in fruit\. Hérical\, Vosges\, 10 Aug\.\, 1855\.
a\. Stem and inflorescence\. Stewart\, 'Punjab Plants'\, p\. 261\.
a\. Plant in fruit\. Little Baddow\, Essex\, 31 July\, 1872\. b\. Plant in fruit\. Reggio\, Calabria\, 15 May\, 1872
a\. Plant in flower\. Kew\, 25 July\, 1858\.
a\. Plant in fruit\. Witham\, Essex\; 31 July\, 1872\.
a\. Plant in fruit\. Near Witham\, Essex\; 31 July\, 1872\. [The glumes are densely clothed with oppressed silky hairs\.]
b\. Ditto\. Instituto Agrario\, Castelnuovo\, Palermo\; 21 May\, 1872\; Filices\. [The glumes are glabrous\.]
